current_status.test_policy_details: Beginning in the 2020-2021 application year, The Catholic University of America implemented a test-blind policy. This means the Committee on Admission will not consider standardized tests (SAT or ACT scores) as part of the review for admission, the University Honors Program, the Cornerstone Scholars Program, or for any merit scholarships. This policy applies to all undergraduate applicants, including home-schooled and international candidates. However, international students whose native language is not English are still required to demonstrate English proficiency through exams such as TOEFL or IELTS.
current_status.notes: The Catholic University of America has an overall acceptance rate of approximately 82-86%. The university does not distinguish between local and international students in its admission statistics. International students comprise about 8.6% of the student body.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Applicants increased by 14.30% (840 applicants) compared to the previous year (2024).
Reported as having the highest number of incoming students in the last 5 years. [cite: 16 in prev step]
Yield rate inferred using the average admission yield over the past 10 years due to lack of specific year-2021 data.

gpa.notes: The average weighted GPA for admitted students is 3.51. The 25th percentile for weighted GPA is 3.3, and the 75th percentile is 3.7. For unweighted GPAs, the 25th percentile is 3.0 and the 75th percentile is 3.6, with an average unweighted GPA of 3.3. Other sources report the average unweighted GPA for admitted students ranging from approximately 3.4 to 3.52. Information regarding '89% in top 10% of class' was not found in the search results.

testing.policy_note: The Catholic University of America is test-optional and allows superscoring. Scores are considered in a holistic review if submitted, but applicants are not disadvantaged if they choose not to submit. The submission rate of 57.0% is based on first-year applicants for Fall 2020, during a period when the university operated under a test-optional policy.

demographics.notes: Information on the percentage of first-generation college students and legacy students for The Catholic University of America was not explicitly found in the provided search results. While 'First-generation students' were mentioned in the context of mental health support, a specific percentage of the student body was not available.

colleges.name: Conway School of Nursing

majors.name: Nursing
prerequisite_courses: PHIL 201 The Classical Mind: The Origin and Growth of Western Philosophy
TRS 201 Foundations of Theology I: Scripture and Jesus Christ
NURS 151 Introduction to Health Systems and Professions
PHIL 202 The Modern Mind: Philosophy from Descartes to the Present
TRS 202A or TRS 202B The Church and the Human Person
CHEM 109 General, Organic, and Biochemistry for the Health Sciences
CHEM 119 General, Organic and Biochemistry for Health Sciences Laboratory
majors.minimum_gpa_to_declare: 2.75 Science GPA and 3.0 Overall GPA for progression
weeder_courses: HESI Nursing Progression Exam (minimum 75% overall composite, 75% in science, English, math composites)
majors.special_requirements: Completion of HESI Nursing Progression Exam at the end of freshman year. Students not meeting scores receive remediation and may retake once.
majors.admissions_pathway: Direct Admit for Traditional 4-year BSN; Accelerated BSN (ABSN) for second-degree students

core_courses: PHIL 201 The Classical Mind: The Origin and Growth of Western Philosophy
TRS 201 Foundations of Theology I: Scripture and Jesus Christ
NURS 151 Introduction to Health Systems and Professions
PHIL 202 The Modern Mind: Philosophy from Descartes to the Present
TRS 202A or TRS 202B The Church and the Human Person
CHEM 109 General, Organic, and Biochemistry for the Health Sciences
CHEM 119 General, Organic and Biochemistry for Health Sciences Laboratory
NURS 254A Health and Wellness Across the Life Span
NURS 275L Adults in Health and Illness - Lecture
NURS 275C Adults in Health and Illness - Clinical I
NURS 423 Women in Health and Illness Lecture
NURS 428 Women in Health and Illness: Clinical Applications
TRS 333 or PHIL 303 Biomedical Ethics (required religion course)

majors.notes: Traditional 4-year BSN and 12-month Accelerated BSN programs are offered. The undergraduate nursing program is ranked 28th in the Nation by U.S. News & World Report.. ABSN program requires a bachelor's degree in a non-nursing field, undergraduate GPA of 3.0, and TEAS score of 58.7 or HESI of 80. Prerequisites for ABSN can be completed online at CUA starting Fall 2025.. Data source: The Catholic University of America Undergraduate Announcements 2025-2026

colleges.housing_profile: Standard university housing (single-sex residence halls for undergraduates, required for first six semesters; limited on-campus options for graduate students, with off-campus guidance). Residence halls offer traditional, suite, and apartment styles, all with laundry, heating, and A/C.
colleges.student_archetype: Compassionate and dedicated students aspiring to a nursing career, with a strong emphasis on holistic patient care (mind, body, and spirit). They engage in extensive clinical affiliations, simulation labs, and are encouraged to pursue summer externships and study abroad opportunities.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Highly recommended for students committed to a service-oriented healthcare profession, who desire a robust nursing education with practical clinical experiences, a holistic approach to patient well-being, and opportunities for global engagement.

colleges.student_archetype: Ethically-minded aspiring business leaders and entrepreneurs who are driven to place human dignity at the center of business. They are interested in entrepreneurship, innovative analysis, experiential learning, and actively engage in the university community and D.C.'s professional opportunities.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for students who want to combine a rigorous business education with strong ethical foundations rooted in Catholic social doctrine, seeking practical skills, real-world experience, and a vibrant community in the nation's capital.

colleges.housing_profile: Primarily caters to adult learners with online, evening, and accelerated course formats. On-campus housing is generally not available for non-traditional students, but Housing Services offers guidance for off-campus options.
colleges.student_archetype: Working professionals, adult learners, and military personnel seeking flexible and career-focused degree or certificate programs. They value small class sizes, personalized advising, and resources for professional development and career advancement.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for non-traditional students who require flexibility in their academic schedule, are motivated by career advancement, and seek a supportive learning environment tailored to adult learners, with a focus on practical skills and leveraging D.C. professional networks.

colleges.housing_profile: Standard university housing (single-sex residence halls for undergraduates, required for first six semesters; limited on-campus options for graduate students, with off-campus guidance). Additionally, religiously affiliated housing options are available, such as Theological College (for summer programs, often priests/religious) and Franciscan Monastery (for clergy and religious, with private baths, meals), and Centro Maria Residence and Casa Sacri Cuori for single young women.
colleges.student_archetype: Students with a deep commitment to their faith who seek to explore theological and religious studies within the Catholic intellectual tradition. This includes individuals discerning religious vocations and laypeople desiring to deepen their understanding of Catholicism and its contemporary relevance, often valuing community and spiritual formation.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for individuals with a strong spiritual foundation and an academic interest in theology or religious studies, including those pursuing religious life. Ideal for students who desire a faith-integrated learning and living environment and wish to engage with the rich Catholic resources of Washington D.C.'s 'Little Rome' community.

supplemental_requirements.details: A completed Common Application with the Common Application Essay is required. Additionally, for the 2025-2026 application cycle, applicants must answer the question: 'As you consider your college and career aspirations, please describe why you are interested in attending The Catholic University of America? (750 words max.)' and three shorter questions (300 characters each) asking to know the applicant better. An additional statement is encouraged for home-schooled applicants explaining the choice of home schooling.

supplemental_requirements.deadline: Undergraduate online-only submissions: January 15, 2026 (application), February 4, 2026 (materials grace period); Graduate online-only submissions: July 31, 2026 (rolling basis)
supplemental_requirements.details: Acceptance requires both university application and an audition for the program of interest, submitted via the Acceptd platform. Specific requirements vary by degree: BA in Music/Performance requires an audition on a principal instrument/voice. Master in Music requires a 10-minute audition with classical repertoire (memorized). Doctoral programs in performance require a 10-15 minute audition with classical repertoire. Auditionees are considered for scholarships.

Students wishing to study composition (BA) must submit original compositions. Master of Music and Doctor of Musical Arts in Composition applicants must submit a representative portfolio of compositions for review by the composition committee, which should include scores and recordings (if available). Doctoral portfolios for composition should include a major thesis work, a major work for large forces, a chamber work, and a vocal work.
A Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Drama does not require an audition.

Submission of a portfolio is optional for incoming freshmen in Fall 2024. The optional design portfolio demonstrates creative productivity, artistry, craft, problem-solving, and illustration potential. It should be a PDF, maximum 20 pages and 20 MB, and can include architectural and/or visual creative work. Portfolios should be emailed to CUA Admissions (cua-admissions@cua.edu).

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Architecture (Graduate - Master of Architecture Three-Year Program)
supplemental_requirements.details: Admission to the 600-level design studios is based on portfolio review and approval.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Holistic review emphasizing academic preparation, character, and a commitment to a global and diverse community. Offers significant support programs for first-generation students.

essay_prompts.prompt: Some students have a background, identity, interest, or talent that is so meaningful they believe their application would be incomplete without it. If this sounds like you, then please share your story.
brainstorming_questions: What aspect of your background, identity, interest, or talent genuinely defines a significant part of who you are today?
How has this particular element influenced your perspective, decisions, or aspirations?
Can you recall a specific moment or series of events where this aspect played a pivotal role?
If you couldn't include this in your application, what important insight about yourself would be missing?
How might this unique part of your story enrich a college community like Catholic University of America?

essay_prompts.prompt: The lessons we take from obstacles we encounter can be fundamental to later success. Recount a time when you faced a challenge, setback, or failure. How did it affect you, and what did you learn from the experience?
brainstorming_questions: Describe a specific challenge, setback, or failure you experienced. What was the context and what were the initial emotions you felt?
What concrete steps did you take to address or overcome this obstacle?
Beyond simply resolving the issue, how did this experience change your approach to future difficulties or your understanding of your own capabilities?
Was there a moment of realization or a turning point during this experience that shifted your perspective?
How has the lesson learned from this challenge manifested in your actions or decisions since then?

essay_prompts.prompt: Reflect on a time when you questioned or challenged a belief or idea. What prompted your thinking? What was the outcome?
brainstorming_questions: What was a specific belief or idea (personal, cultural, academic, etc.) that you once held or encountered and then questioned?
What specific event, piece of information, or conversation triggered your critical examination of this belief?
What internal or external conflicts arose as you questioned or challenged it?
How did your perspective evolve, and what was the ultimate impact on your understanding of yourself or the world?
What did you learn about the process of critical thinking, conviction, or intellectual bravery from this experience?

essay_prompts.prompt: Reflect on something that someone has done for you that has made you happy or thankful in a surprising way. How has this gratitude affected or motivated you?
brainstorming_questions: Who was the person, and what was the specific action or gesture they performed?
Why was this act surprising, and what made it stand out from other kind deeds?
How did this experience initially make you feel, and how has that feeling resonated over time?
In what tangible ways has this gratitude influenced your own behavior, aspirations, or interactions with others?
What deeper understanding of connection, generosity, or human nature did this experience give you?

essay_prompts.prompt: Discuss an accomplishment, event, or realization that sparked a period of personal growth and a new understanding of yourself or others.
brainstorming_questions: What specific accomplishment, event, or realization immediately comes to mind when you think of significant personal growth?
What was your state of mind or understanding *before* this experience?
Describe the moment or process through which this growth or new understanding began to unfold.
How did this experience fundamentally alter your self-perception or your view of other people?
What lasting changes in your character, habits, or ambitions resulted from this period of growth?

essay_prompts.prompt: Describe a topic, idea, or concept you find so engaging that it makes you lose all track of time. Why does it captivate you? What or who do you turn to when you want to learn more?
brainstorming_questions: What specific topic, idea, or concept immediately draws your full attention, even outside of academic requirements?
What is it about this subject that intellectually or emotionally fascinates you?
Beyond typical coursework, how do you actively pursue and deepen your knowledge in this area (e.g., books, documentaries, experiments, discussions)?
Who are your go-to sources or mentors (authors, professors, online communities, personal connections) when you want to explore this topic further?
How does your engagement with this topic reflect your intellectual curiosity and potential contributions to an academic community?

essay_prompts.prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that responds to a different prompt, or one of your own design.
brainstorming_questions: What story about yourself do you feel is most crucial for the admissions committee to know, even if it doesn't fit a specific category?
Is there a unique perspective, experience, or passion that hasn't been adequately covered elsewhere in your application?
If you had just one chance to truly introduce yourself beyond your grades and activities, what would you choose to highlight?
What existing piece of writing are you most proud of that reveals something authentic and significant about you?
What personal narrative would best showcase your voice, creativity, and ability to reflect meaningfully?

major_selection_tactics: Utilize the Exploratory Major program if undecided.
Embrace the flexibility to change majors.
Align your major choice with personal interests and intellectual curiosity.
college_ranking_tactics: Evaluate Program-Specific Academic Excellence and Reputation: Students should research the specific academic reputation of the individual school or college and its programs (e.g., Nursing, Business, Engineering, Architecture, Theology, Philosophy) within The Catholic University of America. This includes looking at the expertise and engagement of professors within the chosen field, as well as opportunities for specialized research and the rigor of the curriculum.

Assess Career Preparation and Post-Graduation Outcomes by Program: Investigate the internship opportunities, career services, and success rates of graduates from specific schools or majors at CUA. Given its Washington D.C. location, the university offers extensive internship access, which can be a critical factor for various fields of study.

Consider Curriculum Design and Learning Environment: Examine the specific curriculum of the desired program, including the balance between specialized courses and the liberal arts core, which is a foundational element at CUA. Students should also consider class sizes, the quality of teaching, and how faith and reason are integrated into their chosen discipline.

alternate_major_strategy.Initial Application and Flexibility: Students apply to The Catholic University of America with a chosen major. However, the university provides flexibility to change this major, even before a student begins their first semester by contacting the Office of Admission.
alternate_major_strategy.Exploratory Major: For incoming freshmen or sophomores who are undecided about their field of study, CUA offers an

option. Students in this program work closely with advisors to assess their talents and interests, learn about various areas of study, and develop a plan for major selection by the end of their sophomore year.
alternate_major_strategy.Early Declaration for Specific Fields: For majors within professional schools (such as Architecture, Engineering, Music, and Nursing) or the natural sciences (like Biology or Chemistry), it is generally recommended to declare these majors at the beginning of the freshman year to ensure timely graduation.

Internal Transfer Difficulty Notes.Common Occurrence: Changing majors at The Catholic University of America is a common practice, with over two-thirds of students changing their major at least once during their academic career.
Process for Changing Majors: Before First Semester: Students can change the major selected on their application by contacting the Office of Admission.
After Starting Classes: Once classes have begun, students should contact their undergraduate advisor or current major advisor to initiate the change process.
Between Different Schools: If a student wishes to change to a major in a different academic school, they must consult with both their current major advisor and their undergraduate advisor.

For Juniors and Seniors: A change of major for juniors or seniors must be accompanied by a written statement from the new department, outlining conditions for acceptance and a plan for completing required coursework within a specified timeframe.
Internal Transfer Difficulty Notes.No Explicit 'Impacted Majors': is not explicitly used in the provided information, the recommendation to declare majors in professional schools and natural sciences early suggests that a later transfer into these programs might require careful academic planning to meet all requirements on schedule.

cost_of_attendance_breakdown.notes: The housing cost ($20,374.00) includes housing allowance ($11,924) and food allowance ($8,450).

scholarships.name: The Catholic University of America Scholarship (CUA Scholarship)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (February 1 for regular decision)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for up to eight semesters or until degree completion

scholarships.name: Archdiocesan Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application; nominees notified mid-December, requires statement of interest and interviews
scholarships.benefits: For students at the top of their high school class with an 'A' average in a demanding curriculum and significant extracurricular involvement and leadership. Renewable for up to eight semesters or until degree completion, requires continuous full-time enrollment
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration; requires additional steps for finalists

scholarships.name: Most Reverend David M. O'Connell Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with Undergraduate Application for Admission; finalists participate in an interview
scholarships.benefits: Awarded to a student with a demonstrated record of service and commitment to service. Strongly encouraged to submit a service resume
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration; submission of service resume encouraged

scholarships.name: Parish Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Must be completed as part of the admission application process
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for up to four years, for undergraduate first-year and transfer applicants who are parishioners of Catholic churches in the U.S. and its territories
scholarships.application_method: Complete Parish Scholarship information in the Common Application

scholarships.name: Legacy Grant
scholarships.deadline: Awarded at the time of admission
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for up to four years, for new undergraduate first-year and transfer students with a parent, grandparent, or sibling who graduated from Catholic University

scholarships.name: School and Departmental Scholarships
scholarships.benefits: Offered by some schools and departments for students in certain fields. Awards are limited

scholarships.name: International Student Merit Scholarships
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration during the admission process
scholarships.benefits: Available to international students; not eligible for federal or university need-based aid. Based on academic transcripts, English proficiency scores, and Common App essay

ap_policy.general_rule: Scores of 4 or 5 are typically required to receive AP credit for most exams
exceptions: Minimum score requirements and credit hours are determined by individual departments, meaning some exams may have different score requirements or may not be awarded credit.

Specific details for exams like AP Research or Computer Science, including any score higher than 4 or outright denial of credit, are outlined in the university's AP Credit Chart, which was not directly accessible in the search results.
ap_policy.usage: AP credits can count toward a student's major or satisfy Liberal Arts (General Education) requirements.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with qualifying scores (typically 5+) grant credit; SL exams are not accepted for credit.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Undergraduate students can transfer a maximum of 60 earned credit hours; total transfer credits within a baccalaureate degree program are limited to half (usually 60 credit hours). Courses must be passed with a grade of at least C. Graduate students may transfer six credit hours of graduate work (up to 9 credits for programs 40+ credits) with a grade of B or above for a master's degree, earned within 5 years of the request. Doctoral students may transfer up to 24 credit hours with a grade of B or better, earned within 10 years of the request. Courses used toward another bachelor's-level degree are not eligible for transfer for a bachelor's degree. Certain business or economics online courses are not transferable unless from an AACSB-accredited institution.

common_activities: Leadership in school clubs and student government.
essay_tips: Show, Don't Tell with Concrete Examples: Instead of simply stating your qualities or experiences, illustrate them with specific anecdotes and details. Successful essays often use vivid descriptions to make your story memorable and demonstrate your points effectively.

Embrace Authenticity and Uniqueness: Strive to reveal something genuinely unique about yourself that might not be evident elsewhere in your application. Avoid generic statements and focus on personal reflections that showcase your individual perspective, self-awareness, and resilience.

Reflect on Your Experiences and Growth: When discussing an experience, accomplishment, or challenge, clearly articulate what you did, why it was important to you, and what you learned from it. Colleges want to understand how you've grown and what these experiences reveal about your character and potential.

Connect Your Interests to the University's Mission (if applicable): While not a specific prompt found in the search, for a Catholic university, considering how your values, academic interests, or personal goals align with CUA's mission as a faith-based institution can strengthen your essay, especially if you choose to write about a topic that allows for such a connection.
red_flags: Significant decline in grades, particularly C's and D's, in academic coursework.
Generic essays that do not demonstrate genuine interest.
Poor or uninformative letters of recommendation from teachers.

insights.insight: The Catholic University of America has a 'somewhat selective' to 'lightly selective' admissions process with an acceptance rate typically around 83-84%. Early Decision and Early Action options are available.
insights.implication: While the acceptance rate is relatively high, applying Early Decision or Early Action by the November 1st deadline can demonstrate strong commitment and potentially increase admission chances.

insights.insight: CUA emphasizes a strong liberal arts core alongside robust professional programs in areas like nursing, business, engineering, and architecture. Its Washington, D.C. location provides unique access to internships and research opportunities.
insights.implication: Highlight your interest in a well-rounded education, connect your academic passions to specific strong programs at CUA, and emphasize any relevant experiences that demonstrate a desire to leverage the D.C. location for internships or experiential learning.

insights.insight: The university fosters a strong sense of community rooted in its Catholic identity, while also welcoming students from diverse backgrounds. There's an emphasis on personal growth, ethical leadership, and a variety of student organizations.
insights.implication: Showcase how your values align with a faith-informed educational environment, express your interest in community engagement, and highlight experiences that demonstrate leadership, service, and an ability to thrive in a diverse yet close-knit setting.

insights.insight: Catholic University has a test-optional admissions policy, focusing instead on a holistic review of an applicant's high school curriculum, performance, recommendations, and essay as the best indicators of future success.
insights.implication: Applicants should focus on demonstrating strong academic performance in challenging high school courses, securing compelling letters of recommendation, and crafting a thoughtful essay, as these elements will be heavily weighted in the absence of standardized test scores.

outcomes.notes: The employment rate of 90.0% represents identified graduates from the Class of 2020 who are either employed, attending graduate school, or committed to other endeavors, not strictly an employment rate 2 years after graduation. Median earnings 10 years after enrollment are sourced from the U.S. Department of Education College Scorecard.
